standard_metadata.standard_description: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.

question.content: **Which of the following numbers is equivalent to $10^3$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
### What does $10^3$ mean?  $10^3=10 \times 10 \times 10$

### How does the exponent relate to the number of zeros?  Each time we multiply by $10$, the value becomes $10$ times larger.  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
### The answer  $10^3$ is equivalent to $1000$.

question.content: **Which of the following numbers is equivalent to $10^4$ ?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
### What does $10^4$ mean?  $10^4 = 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10$

### How does the exponent relate to the number of zeros?  Each time we multiply by $10$, the value becomes $10$ times larger.  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros $10^\maroonD{4} = $ | $10\times10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\maroonD{0{,}000}$ | which has $\maroonD{4}$  zeros
### The answer  $10^4$ is equivalent to $10{,}000$.

question.content: **Which of the following numbers is equivalent to $10^5$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
### What does $10^5$ mean?  $10^5=10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10$

### How does the exponent relate to the number of zeros?  Each time we multiply by $10$, the value becomes $10$ times larger.  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros $10^\maroonD{4} = $ | $10\times10\times10 \times10= $ | $1\maroonD{0{,}000}$ | which has $\maroonD{4}$  zeros $10^\tealD{5} = $ | $10\times10\times10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\tealD{00{,}000}$ | which has $\tealD{5}$  zeros
### The answer  $10^5$ is equivalent to $100{,}000$.

question.content: **Which of the following numbers is equivalent to $10^6$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
### What does $10^6$ mean?  $10^6=10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10 \times 10$

### How does the exponent relate to the number of zeros?  Each time we multiply by $10$, the value becomes $10$ times larger.  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros $10^\maroonD{4} = $ | $10\times10\times10 \times10= $ | $1\maroonD{0{,}000}$ | which has $\maroonD{4}$  zeros $10^\tealD{5} = $ | $10\times10\times10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\tealD{00{,}000}$ | which has $\tealD{5}$  zeros $10^\goldD{6} = $ | $10\times10\times10\times10\times10\times10 = $ | $1{,}\goldD{000{,}000}$ | which has $\goldD{6}$  zeros
### The answer  $10^6$ is equivalent to $1{,}000{,}000$.

question.content: **Which of the following is equivalent to $100$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $100$?
$1\purpleC{00}$ has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros.
###The answer  $100 =  10^\purpleC{2}$

question.content: **Which of the following is equivalent to $1000$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $1000$?
$1\greenD{000}$ has $\greenD{3}$ zeros.
###The answer  $1000 =  10^\greenD{3}$

question.content: **Which of the following is equivalent to $10{,}000$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $10{,}000$?
$1\maroonD{0{,}000}$ has $\maroonD{4}$ zeros.
###The answer  $10{,}000 =  10^\maroonD{4}$

question.content: **Which of the following is equivalent to $100{,}000$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $100{,}000$?
$1\tealD{00{,}000}$ has $\tealD{5}$ zeros.

question.content: **Which of the following is equivalent to $1{,}000{,}000$?**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $1{,}000{,}000$?
$1{,}\goldD{000{,}000}$ has $\goldD{6}$ zeros.

question.content: **Match each expression to its exponential form.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###First, let's write $10\times 10$ with exponents.     $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\purpleC2$ times, so $\purpleC2$ is our exponent: $10^\purpleC2$.

###Next, let's write $10\times 10\times 10\times 10$ with exponents.     $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\maroonD4$ times, so $\maroonD4$ is our exponent: $10^\maroonD4.$

###Finally, let's look at how powers of $10$ are related to the number of zeros.  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  So, the solution for $10^\greenD3$ has $\greenD3$ zeros.
###The answer  Exponent | Expression - | - | - $10^2$ | $10\times10$ $10^3$ | $1000$ $10^4$ | $10\times10\times10\times10$

question.content: **Match each expression to its exponential form.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###First, let's write $10\times 10\times 10$ with exponents.    $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\greenD3$ times, so $\greenD3$ is our exponent: $10^\greenD3$.

###Now, let's look at how powers of $10$ are related to the number of zeros.   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  So, the solution for $10^\blueD1$ has $\blueD1$ zero and $10^\goldD5$ has $\goldD5$ zeros.
###The answer  Exponent | Expression - | - | - $10^1$ | $10$ $10^3$ | $10\times10\times10$ $10^5$ | $100{,}000$

question.content: **Match each expression to its exponential form.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###First, let's write $10\times 10\times 10\times 10\times10$ with exponents.     $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\tealD5$ times, so $\tealD5$ is our exponent: $10^\tealD5$.

###Now, let's look at how powers of $10$ are related to the number of zeros.   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  So, the solution for $10^\purpleC2$ has $\purpleC2$ zeros and $10^\maroonD4$ has $\maroonD4$ zeros.
###The answer  Exponent | Expression - | - | - $10^2$ | $100$ $10^4$ | $10{,}000$ $10^5$ | $10\times 10\times 10\times 10\times10$

question.content: **Match each expression to its exponential form.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###First, let's write $10\times 10\times 10$ with exponents.    $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\greenD3$ times, so $\greenD3$ is our exponent: $10^\greenD3$.

###Next, let's write $10\times 10\times 10\times 10$ with exponents.    $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\maroonD4$ times, so $\maroonD4$ is our exponent: $10^\maroonD4.$

###Finally, let's look at how powers of $10$ are related to the number of zeros.  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  So, the solution for $10^\goldD6$ has $\goldD6$ zeros.
###The answer  Exponent | Expression - | - | - $10^3$ | $10\times10\times10$ $10^4$ | $10\times10\times10\times10$ $10^6$ | $1{,}000{,}000$

question.content: **Match each expression to its exponential form.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###First, let's write $10\times 10\times 10\times 10\times10\times10$ with exponents.     $10$ is the number being multiplied, so it is our base: $10^?$.  $10$ is being multiplied $\goldD6$ times, so $\goldD6$ is our exponent: $10^\goldD6$.

###Now, let's look at how powers of $10$ are related to the number of zeros.   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros

###The answer  Exponent | Expression - | - | - $10^2$ | $100$ $10^5$ | $100{,}000$ $10^6$ | $10\times 10\times 10\times 10\times10\times10$

question.content: **Use the cards to create an expression that is equivalent to $10^2$.**   *Some cards may  not be used.*

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

In the expression, the base is $10$, and the exponent is $2$.   The exponent says how many times to use the base in a multiplication expression.  In $10^2$, the $2$ says to use $10$ twice in a multiplication expression.

question.content: **Use the cards to create an expression that is equivalent to $10^3$.**   *Some cards may  not be used.*

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

In the expression, the base is $10$, and the exponent is $3$.   The exponent says how many times to use the base in a multiplication expression.  In $10^3$, the $3$ says to use $10$ three times in a multiplication expression.
$10^3=10\times10\times10$

question.content: **Use the cards to create an expression that is equivalent to $10^4$.**   *Some cards may  not be used.*

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

In the expression, the base is $10$, and the exponent is $4$.   The exponent says how many times to use the base in a multiplication expression.  In $10^4$, the $4$ says to use $10$ four times in a multiplication expression.
$10^4=10\times10\times10\times10$

hints.content: ###What is a power? question.content: **Use the cards to create an expression that is equivalent to $10^6$.**   *Some cards may  not be used.*

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

In the expression, the base is $10$, and the exponent is $6$.   The exponent says how many times to use the base in a multiplication expression.  In $10^6$, the $6$ says to use $10$ six times in a multiplication expression.
$10^6=10\times10\times10\times10\times10\times10$

question.content: **What exponent will make this equation true?**  $10^?=100$  $?=$

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $100$?
$1\purpleC{00}$ has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros.
###The answer  $10^\purpleC{2}=100$

For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $1000$?
$1\greenD{000}$ has $\greenD{3}$ zeros.
###The answer  $10^\greenD{3}=1000$

question.content: **What exponent will make this equation true?**  $10^?=10{,}000$  $?=$

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?   | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $10{,}000$?
$1\maroonD{0{,}000}$ has $\maroonD{4}$ zeros.
###The answer  $10^\maroonD{4}=10{,}000 $

question.content: **What exponent will make this equation true?**  $10^?=100{,}000$  $?=$

A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $100{,}000$?
$1\tealD{00{,}000}$ has $\tealD{5}$ zeros.

question.content: **What exponent will make this equation true?**  $10^?=1{,}000{,}000$  $?=$

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

###How do powers of $10$ relate to the number of zeros?  | | | |  -: | -: | -: | :-: | :- $10^\blueD{1} = $ | $10 = $ | $1\blueD{0}$ | which has $\blueD{1}$ zero $10^\purpleC{2} = $ | $10\times10 = $| $1\purpleC{00}$| which has $\purpleC{2}$ zeros $10^\greenD{3} = $ | $10\times10\times10 = $ | $1\greenD{000}$ | which has $\greenD{3}$  zeros
We can see that for powers of $10$, the number of zeros is the same as the exponent of $10$.  How many zeros are in $1{,}000{,}000$?
$1{,}\goldD{000{,}000}$ has $\goldD{6}$ zeros.
